newsitem.title: USA: NASD should drop bond fund risk ratings curbs--S&P.
newsitem.headline: NASD should drop bond fund risk ratings curbs--S&P.

text.p: Standard & Poor's has urged the National Association of Securities Dealers to permit bond funds to provide risk ratings developed by rating agencies to potential investors.

"Research clearly shows that investors want more information about the market risk factors that could affect their mutual bond funds," S&P President Leo O'Neill said in a 10-page comment letter delivered late Monday to NASD.

S&P Ratings Group in 1994 launched a service to rate the risk of bond funds, including municipal bond funds. But NASD, which regulates mutual fund advertising, ruled that funds may not use such ratings in sales literature.
NASD said it was worried that the ratings could mislead investors because they hinge on "assumptions and speculation" about the economy in general and about a company's solvency.
Nevertheless, NASD reopened the issue in December by calling for a new round of comments, which are due this week.

O'Neill said S&P's three-year-old risk ratings have demonstrated that they can accurately depict a fund's volatility. He noted the past few years, particularly 1994, have been marked by unusual volatility.
S&P's president said NASD's recent position is "puzzling" since NASD has permitted localities to include credit ratings in sales documents for years.

Risk ratings provide investors with valuable, additional information, O'Neill said. "The current prohibition is contrary to the public interest, ill-serves investors, stifles competition among bond funds, and otherwise is without merit," O'Neill said.
Mutual funds can still get market risk ratings from S&P, but NASD policy bars funds from distributing the ratings in advertising and supplement sales materials.
S&P has made repeated requests since 1994 for NASD to drop the restriction.
